awd_abstract_narration:
Wireless networking assumes that radios are half-duplex. On a given frequency, a half-duplex radio can either transmit or receive, but not both at the same time. The project disproves this long-held assumption; it shows how a radio that can transmit and receive simultaneously on the same frequency can be built using commodity off-the-shelf components.  The design is based on two key ideas. First, is the design of analog circuits that can perform adaptive signal inversion, i.e. take an input RF signal and produce its exact inverse, and programmatically adapt the attenuation and delay on the inverted signal to match the self-interference experienced by the received signal.  This enables the design of wideband full duplex radios that can handle transmit powers upto 20dBm. Second, the project exploits the full duplex primitive to design a real-time bidirectional channel for control and data, as well as more complex patterns such as chains. By interspersing control and data information in a message, nodes can dynamically react to channel changes in real-time.

The above two primitives - full-duplex operation and a real-time bidirectional control channel - can help solve many long-standing fundamental problems in wireless networks, including hidden terminals, bitrate adaptation, network congestion, resource allocation and unfairness. The project will produce a prototype full duplex radio for WiFi style networks and show experimentally how it can improve their performance, further all designs will also be made public through research publications and open-source hardware designs.

por.por_cntn:
A long held assumption in wireless is that radios cannot transmit and receive simultaneously on the same frequency. This basic assumption has guided every aspect of wireless design across the entire network. The research in this project invalidated this basic assumption, it invented radios that can successfully transmit and receive simultaneously on the same frequency. The designs and prototypes were the first ever to show true in-band full duplex capability for widely used technologies such as WiFi.

The core challenge in realizing in-band full duplex capability is self-interference, i.e the interference a radio’s own transmission causes to its own receiver that’s attempting to receive another signal. The key contributions of this research were self-interference cancellation algorithms and hardware/software systems that could completely cancel the self-interference to the noise floor. We invented novel estimation and signal processing algorithms that were realized in a combination of analog circuits and digital signal processing software, and prototypes demonstrated nearly complete self-interference cancellation of around 110dB for radios transmitting at 20dBm (e.g WiFi). To the best of our knowledge, this was the world’s first demonstration of in-band full duplex for WiFi and the highest level of self-interference cancellation ever demonstrated. The research effort realized self-interference cancellation designs for a wide variety of bandwidths from 5Mhz to 80MHz as well as for MIMO scenarios with up to three antennas.

We also showed that self-interference cancellation is a basic and powerful capability that can be used for a wide variety of applications. Specifically, we showed how self-interference cancellation enables radios that can transmit and receive simultaneously on arbitrary spectrum fragments, thereby enabling wireless systems to take advantage of fragmented unlicensed spectrum efficiently. We also built full duplex relays that can simultaneously receive, amplify and relay a signal to enhance throughput and coverage. Finally, we showed that self-interference cancellation has applications beyond traditional communications. For example, we built a passive, device-free motion tracing system that can trace fine-grained human motion by looking at the reflections of WiFi signal transmissions. Self-interference cancellation is critical because it enables a radio to listen to its own transmission’s reflections and mine it to implement motion tracing. Finally, in recent work we showed how self-interference cancellation can be used to build very low power battery-less communication that achieves a throughput of up to 5Mbps and ranges up to 5m by enabling low power tags to intelligently reflect standard WiFi transmissions and modulate their own data.

Our work has had significant impact. Full duplex as well as flexible duplex are now considered core building blocks of the 5G wireless standard which is going to succeed LTE. All major standards bodies as well as several major network vendors are now incorporating full duplex as a key piece in the 5G roadmap. Our research was also spun off into a startup that is commercializing full duplex and has already demonstrated successful field trials of the technology with major cellular operators. Academically, several research groups across the world have now embarked on large projects on full duplex and our early papers have now been cited several hundred times just in the last two years alone.
